title: Revised Project Proposal: WeatherXplore
text: This project aims to develop an interactive visual analytics tool for Singapore’s climate data. While historical weather data is publicly available, existing platforms lack comprehensive visualizations, advanced forecasting capabilities, and spatial interpolation techniques. Our solution will integrate various R packages to provide in-depth climate analytics.

title: About
text: Despite the availability of weather forecasts, many individuals and industries lack customized, data-driven insights that help them plan effectively. WeatherXplore democratizes access to weather analytics by integrating advanced data visualization and predictive modeling techniques into a user-friendly interface. The application will assist users in optimizing their daily activities, selecting appropriate clothing, and planning outdoor events based on weather patterns. Additionally, it will provide insights into climate trends and extreme weather events, benefiting policymakers, researchers, and the general public.

title: WeatherXplore
text: Welcome to WeatherXplore! An interactive analytics platform for smarter living.

title: Revised Project Proposal: WeatherXplore
text: This project aims to develop an interactive visual analytics tool for Singapore’s climate data. While historical weather data is publicly available, existing platforms lack comprehensive visualizations, advanced forecasting capabilities, and spatial interpolation techniques. Our solution will integrate various R packages to provide in-depth climate analytics.

title: Revised Project Proposal: WeatherXplore
text:
2. Motivation
Singapore’s National Environment Agency provides access to historical weather data, but the available tools lack interactivity, comparative analysis, and advanced statistical modeling. This project addresses these gaps by:

Providing interactive and comparative visualizations of weather trends.
Conducting advanced time-series forecasting for rainfall and temperature.
Utilizing geospatial interpolation techniques to estimate weather conditions at unmonitored locations.

title: Revised Project Proposal: WeatherXplore
text:
3. The Problems Addressed

Current government tools are static and offer limited interactivity.
No existing system provides an integrated platform for time-series analysis and forecasting.
Spatial interpolation is missing, restricting accurate weather estimations beyond monitored stations.

title: Revised Project Proposal: WeatherXplore
text:
4. Data Sources

Climate Historical Daily Records (Weather.gov.sg)
The Meteorological Service Singapore provides a publicly accessible repository of historical daily weather data. The dataset includes:

Temperature and Rainfall Data: Recorded at 19 weather stations across Singapore.
Time Span: 5 years (2019-2024), providing a rich dataset to analyze weather trends and variations.
Data Frequency: Daily records capturing temperature highs/lows and total rainfall.
Spatial Coverage: Covers multiple monitoring stations, offering regional weather insights.
Missing Data Handling: Any gaps in the dataset are addressed through imputation techniques such as simple moving averages.
Data Format: The dataset is available in structured tabular formats, making it suitable for integration with R-based analytical tools.
Source: Data retrieved from Weather.gov.sg, ensuring credibility and consistency with Singapore’s official climate records.




Dataset
Frequency
Period
Source




Climate Historical Daily Records (rainfall, temperature)
Daily
2019-2024
https://www.weather.gov.sg/climate-historical-daily/

title: Revised Project Proposal: WeatherXplore
text:
5. Approach and Methodology
The tool will be developed in R Shiny, divided into three core modules:

5.1 Exploratory & Confirmatory Data Analysis (Priya)

Analyzing temperature and rainfall variations over five years.
Ridge plots to visualize station-wise trends over time.
Calendar heatmaps to capture daily temperature changes.
Comparative statistical tests to validate observed patterns.



5.2 Time Series Analysis & Forecasting (Phoo)

Decomposition of time-series data into trend, seasonal, and white noise components.
Implementation of ARIMA and exponential smoothing models for forecasting.
Model validation and performance comparison.



5.3 Geospatial Analysis (Kenneth)

Geofacet visualizations to compare weather variations across different locations.
Spatial interpolation to estimate rainfall and temperature beyond monitored stations.
Using Singapore’s official climate datasets for interpolation techniques.



5.4 Data Preparation

Consolidation of multiple datasets into a structured format.
Handling missing values and standardizing variable names.
Code implementation to combine and clean datasets efficiently.

title: Revised Project Proposal: WeatherXplore
text:
7. Expected Outcome

A web-based visual analytics tool allowing users to explore historical and predictive weather trends interactively.
Advanced time-series forecasting with seasonal adjustments.
Geospatial interpolation to estimate climate parameters at unmonitored locations.
An interactive dashboard enabling policymakers, researchers, and the general public to derive meaningful insights.

title: Revised Project Proposal: WeatherXplore
text:
8. Tools & Technologies

R Packages: tidyverse, dplyr, lubridate, tidygraph, ggraph, visNetwork, ggplot2, shiny, leaflet, sf.

title: Project Proposal
text:
WeatherXplore: Interactive Analytics for Smarter Living

1. Project Overview
Weather significantly impacts daily life, influencing outdoor activities, travel, public safety, and health. Understanding historical weather trends and real-time data can provide valuable insights for better decision-making. This project aims to develop a web-enabled interactive analytics platform using Shiny that enables users to explore and analyze weather data in Singapore.
Our goal is to democratize access to weather analytics by integrating advanced data visualization and predictive modeling techniques into a user-friendly interface. The application will assist users in optimizing their daily activities, selecting appropriate clothing, and planning outdoor events based on weather patterns. Additionally, it will provide insights into climate trends and extreme weather events, benefiting policymakers, researchers, and the general public.


2. Problem Statement
Despite the availability of weather forecasts, many individuals and industries lack customized, data-driven insights that help them plan effectively. The challenges include:

Uncertainty in Outdoor Planning: Users struggle with unpredictable rainfall, high UV levels, and fluctuating temperatures when scheduling activities.
Health Risks from Weather Exposure: Extreme temperatures and UV levels pose risks such as heatstroke, dehydration, and skin damage.
Lack of Data-Driven Travel & Activity Recommendations: Current weather apps provide forecasts but do not offer historical trend analysis to guide travel and event planning.
Limited Awareness of Severe Weather Conditions: There is a need for real-time alerts on extreme weather events to enhance preparedness and safety.



3. Related Work
Several existing weather applications, including Google Weather, Apple Weather, and AccuWeather, provide real-time forecasts but lack interactive historical trend analysis and personalized recommendations. The Meteorological Service Singapore (MSS) offers online reports, but these are often static and do not allow dynamic data exploration.
Our project enhances existing functionalities by integrating interactive dashboards, predictive analytics, and real-time safety alerts, providing users with actionable weather insights tailored to their needs.


4. Project Objectives

Develop an interactive web-based dashboard that visualizes historical and real-time weather data from Meteorological Service Singapore.
Provide weather-aware activity and travel recommendations, helping users plan events and outdoor activities based on temperature, UV index, humidity, and precipitation trends.
Incorporate safety advisories, including UV exposure warnings, clothing recommendations, and severe weather alerts.
Enable interactive filtering and data exploration, allowing users to analyze weather patterns by time period, location, and variable type.
Implement predictive analytics, utilizing machine learning models to estimate future weather trends and patterns.
Ensure accessibility and usability, making the tool suitable for both the general public and specialized users like policymakers and researchers.



5. Methodology
Data Collection: Obtain historical weather data from Visual Crossing and real-time updates from meteorological sources.
Data Preprocessing: Clean and standardize data, handling missing values and ensuring consistency.
Shiny Application Development:

Frontend: Design an interactive dashboard using Shiny UI components.
Backend: Implement data processing and visualization using ggplot2, leaflet, and plotly.
Interactivity Features: Include date filters, region selectors, and variable comparisons.
Deployment: Host the application on shinyapps.io for easy public access.



6. Key Features & Functionality

6.1 Weather-Aware Activity & Travel Planner

Identifies optimal time slots for outdoor activities based on temperature, humidity, UV index, and precipitation trends.
Visual heatmaps and trend graphs to display the best times for outdoor events.
Rainfall trend analysis through line charts and bar graphs to highlight seasonal variations.
Interactive travel and event advisory system integrating both historical data and real-time forecasts.



6.2 UV Index & Skin Safety Advisory

Monitors UV index levels throughout the day.
Provides real-time sunscreen and clothing recommendations to minimize skin damage.
Displays UV index heatmaps and safety alerts.



6.3 Predictive Analytics & Climate Trend Analysis

Implements time series forecasting models to predict future weather trends.
Analyzes long-term climate trends and their potential impacts on Singapore.
Provides insights into climate change indicators using interactive visualizations.




7. Early Prototype
The initial prototype will include:

A homepage with key weather trends and insights.
A dashboard with interactive charts for temperature, precipitation, and humidity trends.
A map-based interface for geospatial weather analysis.
A forecasting section utilizing predictive models to estimate future trends.



8. Project Timeline

title: Data Preparation
text: This document describes the data preparation process for combining and enriching historical weather data for Singapore from 2020 to 2024.

title: Data Preparation
text: This document describes the data preparation process for combining and enriching historical weather data for Singapore from 2020 to 2024.

title: Data Preparation
text:
1. Download Historical Weather Data
Download the daily weather data for each year from the Meteorological Service Singapore website. Save all the CSV files into a single folder.

title: Data Preparation
section: 2. Combine All CSV Files into One Dataset
text:
2. Combine All CSV Files into One Dataset
We used the data.table package to read and combine multiple CSV files stored in one directory.
library(data.table)

file_list <- list.files(pattern = "\\.csv$")

# Read and combine all CSVs
weather_data <- rbindlist(lapply(file_list, fread), fill = TRUE)

title: Data Preparation
section: 3. Convert Year, Month, Day to a Single Date Column
text:
3. Convert Year, Month, Day to a Single Date Column
Assuming each CSV file includes columns for Year, Month, and Day:
# Combine year, month, and day into a proper date
weather_data[, Date := as.Date(paste(Year, Month, Day, sep = "-"))]

# Remove the original columns
weather_data[, c("Year", "Month", "Day") := NULL]

title: Data Preparation
text:
4. Add Region Column
We map the region using a predefined vector based on the station name.
region_map <- c(
  "Admiralty" = "North",
  "Ang Mo Kio" = "Northeast",
  "Changi" = "East",
  "Choa Chu Kang (South)" = "West",
  "Clementi" = "West",
  "East Coast Parkway" = "East",
  "Jurong (West)" = "West",
  "Jurong Island" = "West",
  "Marina Barrage" = "Central",
  "Newton" = "Central",
  "Pasir Panjang" = "Central",
  "Paya Lebar" = "Central",
  "Pulau Ubin" = "Northeast",
  "Seletar" = "North",
  "Sembawang" = "North",
  "Sentosa Island" = "Central",
  "Tai Seng" = "Northeast",
  "Tengah" = "West",
  "Tuas South" = "West"
)

weather_data[, Region := region_map[Station]]

title: Data Preparation
text:
5. Add Latitude and Longitude
We join latitude and longitude coordinates using a reference table.
data_coords <- data.table(
  Station = c("Admiralty", "Ang Mo Kio", "Changi", "Choa Chu Kang (South)", "Clementi", "East Coast Parkway", 
              "Jurong (West)", "Jurong Island", "Marina Barrage", "Newton", "Pasir Panjang", "Paya Lebar", 
              "Pulau Ubin", "Seletar", "Sembawang", "Sentosa Island", "Tai Seng", "Tengah", "Tuas South"),
  Latitude = c(1.4439, 1.3793, 1.3678, 1.3729, 1.3318, 1.3133, 1.3458, 1.2542, 1.2799, 1.3106, 1.2824, 
               1.3571, 1.4168, 1.4167, 1.4250, 1.2503, 1.3406, 1.3858, 1.2938),
  Longitude = c(103.7854, 103.8500, 103.9823, 103.7224, 103.7762, 103.9620, 103.6817, 103.6741, 103.8703, 
                103.8365, 103.7545, 103.9037, 103.9673, 103.8650, 103.8200, 103.8275, 103.8882, 103.7119, 
                103.6184)
)

weather_data <- merge(weather_data, data_coords, by = "Station", all.x = TRUE)

title: Data Preparation
text:
6. Sort Data
Group by station alphabetically and sort dates chronologically within each station.
# Sort data
setorder(weather_data, Station, Date)

title: Data Preparation
section: 9. Check for Duplicates and Missing Values
text:
9. Check for Duplicates and Missing Values
Ensure data integrity by checking for duplicates and missing values.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse, naniar, lubridate)

weather_data_clean <-read_csv("data/weather_data_clean.csv")

Rows: 34124 Columns: 14
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr   (2): Region, Station
dbl  (11): Daily Rainfall Total (mm), Highest 30 min Rainfall (mm), Highest ...
date  (1): Date

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

duplicates <- weather_data_clean %>% 
  filter(duplicated(.))

print(duplicates)

# A tibble: 0 × 14
# ℹ 14 variables: Region <chr>, Station <chr>, Date <date>,
#   Daily Rainfall Total (mm) <dbl>, Highest 30 min Rainfall (mm) <dbl>,
#   Highest 60 min Rainfall (mm) <dbl>, Highest 120 min Rainfall (mm) <dbl>,
#   Mean Temperature (°C) <dbl>, Maximum Temperature (°C) <dbl>,
#   Minimum Temperature (°C) <dbl>, Mean Wind Speed (km/h) <dbl>,
#   Max Wind Speed (km/h) <dbl>, Latitude <dbl>, Longitude <dbl>

vis_miss(weather_data_clean)

title: Data Preparation
text:
7. Convert column data type
Convert data types such that ‘Region’ and ‘Station’ remain as character, ‘Date’ becomes a proper date type and all other columns become numeric.
weather_data_clean <- weather_data %>%
  mutate(
    Date = dmy(Date),  # Convert Date column to Date format (from d/m/yyyy)
    across(
      .cols = -c(Region, Station, Date),  # Select all except these columns
      .fns = ~ as.numeric(.)
    )
  )

title: Data Preparation
section: 8. Export datasets as CSV and RDS
text:
8. Export datasets as CSV and RDS
# Export as CSV
write.csv(weather_data_clean, "weather_data_clean.csv", row.names = FALSE)

# Export as RDS
saveRDS(weather_data_clean, "weather_data_clean.rds")
